name: Game Element
rule: A game element is any physical component of the game, a story passage, or a note the game instructed you to take.

name: Generic Tokens
rule: Use Generic tokens to keep track of anything that you want to; these were added for your convenience. Whenever there’s an effect that doesn’t use any of the specific tokens, you will be instructed to use a generic token to track it.

name: Random
rule: When you are asked to choose a random element, do the following based on the element:

name: Random Card
rule: Draw the top card from the indicated (facedown) deck.

name: Random Direction
rule: Draw the top card from the Minor Trauma deck. The arrow in the bottom left corner designates the randomly chosen direction. If it shows a rotating arrow, you may instead choose a direction. Place the drawn card at the bottom of the deck.

name: Random Element
rule: Roll one d10 for each element, lowest roll is selected.

name: Ignore
rule: “Ignored” elements or rules are not resolved. “Ignore” can be specific instances (accompanied by the word “this”) or constant.

name: Remove
rule: “Removed” elements are set aside and not used until instructed, or until the end of Battle if not.

name: Disable
rule: “Disabled” elements or rules are ignored until stated, or until the end of Battle if not.

name: Discard
rule: “Discarded” elements are Disabled and Removed.

name: Cannot
rule: The term “cannot” is absolute. It cannot be overridden unless explicitly instructed.

name: Gain
rule: Whenever you gain a game element, simply find it and add it to an appropriate place

name: Gaining Gear
rule: Gained Gear cards are added to the Argo Armory deck.

name: Gaining Gear in Battle
rule: If you gain a Gear card during a Battle, the Titan responsible for the gain may immediately equip that card. If the gained card has the Possession keyword, the Titan or Argonaut must immediately equip it.

name: Gaining Tech
rule: Gained Technology cards are added to the Technology deck.

name: Gaining Clues
rule: Gained Clue and Ally cards are placed next to your current Story and Doom cards.

name: Gaining Mnemos cards
rule: Gained Mnemos cards are placed in the play area of the Argonaut who gained them. If it is impossible for any Argonaut to gain a Mnemos card (III.5.5), instead add it to the Mnemos Vault (III.5.6).

name: Gaining Tokens
rule: Gained tokens are placed in the appropriate area.

name: Gaining Battle Tokens
rule: Tokens that have no effect outside of Battle (e.g. Ambrosia or Despair) are held by the Argonaut who gained them.

name: Gaining Other Game Elements
rule: Some game elements are not represented by physical components. If you gain any element that is not represented by a component, note it on either the Argo Sheet or an Argonaut Sheet, whichever is specified.

name: Loss
rule: When you lose a physical component, archive it unless instructed otherwise. When you lose a game element that is not represented by a physical component, erase it from the appropriate sheet (if it is singular) or lower its value by a specified number.

name: Gain/Loss Mitigation
rule: Some Technology abilities may allow you to ignore gaining or losing a specific game element (VIII.6.4.2d).

name: Voluntary Gain/Loss
rule: If the gain/loss is listed in the text of an active ability, story choice (IX.1.3), or any other non-forced effect, it is considered voluntary (a “payment”).

name: Unmitigable Loss
rule: Voluntary gain/loss cannot be mitigated or ignored in any way.

name: Gaining/Losing as a Group
rule: When you are instructed to “gain as a group” or “lose as a group", distribute the specified statistic or element among all of the Argonauts as you see fit; it does not have to be distributed evenly.

name: Archiving (Permanently Removing)
rule: When instructed to Permanently Remove a game element (or Archive it), place it back in the game box. It is no longer considered a part of the game state (though an effect may instruct you to return it).

name: Voluntary/Involuntary
rule: “Voluntary” effects are those which the Titan/Primordial has done with its own action/effect. “Involuntary” effects are any effects which a Titan/Primordial resolves but are not caused by itself.

name: Exhaust
rule: When instructed to exhaust a game element or ability, turn it 90 degrees or place a Generic Token on it to denote this. Cards remain exhausted until they are unexhausted by another effect.

name: Gameplay Flow
rule: This game is played over many sessions. During a game session, you will likely play a few Campaign Rounds. Each Campaign Round is made up of a series of Steps. Each of these Steps incorporates one or more of the game’s Phases: Voyage Phase, Adventure Phase, or Battle Phase.

name: Gameplay Round
rule: A Campaign Round is one in-game day on the Timeline.

name: Steps
rule: Steps make up the structure of a Campaign Round and are always resolved in a fixed order.

name: Phases
rule: Phases are gameplay segments that differentiate which rules are in effect at any moment.

name: Phase Types
rule: There are three different Phases in ATO: Voyage, Battle, and Adventure.

name: Phase Rule of Thumb
rule: You are always in a game Phase. If you’re not in the Adventure Phase or the Battle Phase, you’re in the Voyage Phase.

name: Phase Entering
rule: When you are in a Battle, you are in the Battle Phase. When you are reading passages in the Storybook, you’re in the Adventure Phase. Always return to the Voyage Phase after finishing a Battle or Story section.

name: Phase Campaign Round
rule: Any Campaign Round Step can consist of any combination of Phases.

name: Campaign Round Sequence
rule: Each Campaign Round, you will go through the Campaign Round Steps (VIII.1-10), resolving them in order.

name: Events
rule: All Campaign Round Steps always happen, but there are not always events during a Step in a given Campaign Round. Steps VIII.1-3 always have events.

name: Always Move
rule: During the Movement Step, you must move the Argo to an adjacent Map tile.

name: Ambrosia Limit X/+X
rule: Your Ambrosia Limit becomes X or is increased by X, respectively. If you have more than one instance of the former, then the one with the greatest X is used (before applying modifiers).

name: Armor-Piercing
rule: During the Power Roll, ignore Hardened.
